title: Former UAW President Charged With Conspiring to Embezzle Union Funds
summary: Gary Jones used the money to pay for trips, liquor, other luxuries, prosecutors allege. A federal corruption investigation targeting United Auto Workers leaders has ensnared its highest-ranking official yet: an ex-union president charged with stealing union funds to pay for private villas, expensive cigars, golf outings and other luxuries.

title: U.S. to Make 35,000 Additional Seasonal Worker H-2B Visas Available
summary: Of the total visas available, 10,000 will be reserved for people from Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration said it is making an additional 35,000 seasonal guest-worker visas available this year ahead of the busy summer season, the largest increase since President Trump took office.

title: Amazon Dogged by Price Gouging as Coronavirus Fears Grow
summary: Third-party sellers on the website charging as much as six times the normal price for virus-killing supplies; $50 for a two-pack of Purell. Amazon . com Inc. is struggling to stamp out third-party sellers charging exorbitant prices for virus-killing cleaning supplies, hand sanitizer and other products in high demand amid coronavirus fears.

title: Putin, Erdogan Agree to Cease-Fire in Syria
summary: Fighting in the northwest has triggered a humanitarian disaster and brought Russia and Turkey closer to war. MOSCOW-Russia and Turkey have agreed to a cease-fire in northwestern Syria, where intense fighting has triggered a humanitarian catastrophe and brought the nuclear power and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization member closer to direct war.

title: OPEC Agrees to Drastic Oil Cuts Ahead of Russia Talks
summary: Moscow has yet to agree to a unified OPEC+ response to the coronavirus outbreak. OPEC reached a preliminary agreement to cut crude output by 1 million barrels a day to support oil prices through the end of the year, as the cartel seeks to persuade Russia to join its response to the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Jack Creighton Led Weyerhaeuser, United Airlines Through Crises
summary: Former CEO won plaudits as a conciliator. The adversaries that gave Jack Creighton his reputation as a tough but fair negotiator included machinists at United Airlines and advocates for the northern spotted owl.

title: Costco Rides Coronavirus-Fueled Panic Buying
summary: February comparable sales jump 12.1% as chain scrambles to restock shelves; 'It's been a little crazy this past week'. Sales at Costco Wholesale Corp. stores rose and some items were in short supply as shoppers stocked up on bulk quantities of everyday goods amid the new coronavirus outbreak.

title: U.S. Stocks Drop as Virus Jitters Return
summary: Yield on 10-year Treasury note remains below 1%, signaling investors' concerns about growth. Painful market turbulence resumed Thursday, pulling major stock indexes down more than 3% and government-bond yields to record lows as fears grew over the spread of the coronavirus in the U.S.

title: Elizabeth Warren's Exit Spurs Competition for Her Voters
summary: Backers of Massachusetts progressive split their second-choice picks between Vermont senator, former vice president in earlier polling. WASHINGTON-Elizabeth Warren's departure from the Democratic presidential contest left Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders competing to win over her largely college-educated base of support ahead of a series of primaries over the next month.

title: Rare World Trade Center Blueprints Are Up for Sale
summary: The documents, which carry a six-figure price tag, had been found in the trash. When veteran architect Joseph Solomon left New York City for Denver in the 1970s, he brought along a work-related keepsake: a set of blueprints for the World Trade Center, one of the key projects of his career up until that time.

title: UBS Exits Arctic Oil, Coal Mines and Tar Sands Projects
summary: The Swiss bank said it would no longer finance new offshore-oil projects in the Arctic, thermal coal mines or oil sands on undeveloped land. UBS Group AG said Thursday that it would no longer finance new offshore-oil projects in the Arctic, thermal coal mines or oil sands on undeveloped land as banks tighten their restrictions on fossil fuels amid pressure from environmentalists and investors.

title: CFOs Look to Boost Cash Holdings, Cut Costs Amid Coronavirus Outbreak
summary: Finance executives assess forecasts, funds and scenarios as the virus spreads. Finance chiefs are boosting cash holdings, slashing costs and collecting outstanding payments to ensure their companies remain sufficiently capitalized to withstand financial hits from the coronavirus epidemic.

title: Independent Private Medicine Is a Vital Plus
summary: The desire to put all of America's health-system eggs in one Medicare-for-All basket is hard to fathom.. Your editorial "Private Medicine to the Rescue" (March 2) is a reminder that Americans turn to government when their health or physical security is at risk, but government generally turns to private actors to buttress its response to a crisis. A core U.S. strength is the breadth of its private medical resources. The Food and Drug Administration as well as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are tapping into America's core strength to help test for the coronavirus and to develop a vaccine and therapeutics. The rest of the world piggybacks on medical developments in the U.S., typically at bargain prices.

title: Mexico Isn't Heading Toward One-Man Rule
summary: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador won a landslide victory in Mexico's last presidential election, a free and fair exercise that was a victory for democracy itself.. As recently as 2018, some pundits in the international media said that if President Andrés Manuel López Obrador (AMLO) were elected, Mexico would descend into chaos. However, 15 months into AMLO's presidency, foreign direct investment has increased by 4.2% and the country reported a primary budget surplus of 1.1%. Further, the minimum wage was doubled on the northern border and increased by 36% everywhere else, with an annual inflation rate under 3%. The tale of the irresponsible populist was proved wrong. Now, some international commentators are questioning AMLO's democratic credentials.

title: GDP Growth, Per Capita Growth and Immigration
summary: Where does this myth that President Trump's immigration policies have been "restrictive" come from?. Regarding James K. Glassman's "Where's That 3% Growth?" (op-ed, Feb. 27): The usual plutocratic focus on total GDP ignores the fact that per capita GDP is a better, though hardly perfect, measure of the economic quality of life for most citizens.

title: Democrats Apply a Double Standard to Gag Employers
summary: Apparently the same Democratic politicians who decry the Trump administration's family planning "gag rule" were perfectly content to legally gag a public employer who might discourage an employee from union membership.. Concerning your editorial "California's Janus Jiu Jitsu" (Feb. 25): Apparently the same Democratic politicians who decry the Trump administration's family planning "gag rule" on medical providers, prohibiting abortion support as a birth-control method, were perfectly content to legally gag a public employer who might discourage an employee from union membership or from paying union dues as the law allows.

title: How the Coronavirus Spread From One Patient to 1,000 Now Quarantined in New York
summary: As of Thursday, a total of 22 people in New York had the virus, according to city and state officials. Religious schools have been shut.

title: Coronavirus Keeps Workers at Home
summary: The spread of the illness is testing the ability of companies to stick to normal operations. Companies are urging or requiring employees to work from home, a reaction to the global spread of the new coronavirus that is testing their ability to maintain normal business operations.

title: Chip Maker NXP Nominates Its Next Chief Executive
summary: Kurt Sievers, the company's president, would succeed Rick Clemmer as CEO. NXP Semiconductors NV said its board nominated the company's president to become the new chief executive.

title: NYPD Officials Say New Bail Law Is Leading to a Crime Increase
summary: New York City recorded a rise in overall crime in January and February. New York Police Department officials said Thursday that overall crime in New York City rose by 22.5% in February, attributing the increase to a new law that eliminates bail for defendants accused of low-level and nonviolent offenses.

title: Capitol Hill Stays Open as Lawmakers Fret About Working in 'Petri Dish'
summary: Pelosi says there are no plans to shut down amid coronavirus outbreak. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said there are no plans to close the Capitol building to tourists or members of Congress in the event of a coronavirus outbreak, as lawmakers prepared contingency plans for their offices.

title: Hemp Suppliers at Odds With Hazy Regulations
summary: Authorities have seized truckloads of crops they mistook for marijuana. Farmers cheered when hemp was legalized nationally for the first time in decades. But more than a year later, differing state regulations and law enforcement's unfamiliarity with the plant are complicating efforts to capitalize on the crop.

title: Demand for Face Masks Is Booming, But Makers Have a Nagging Concern: Legal Liability
summary: Makers of N95 respirators are worried about their potential liability amid the coronavirus outbreak and have been seeking protection from Congress. WASHINGTON-Demand for N95 face masks-the kind that keeps out at least 95% of particles-is surging amid more U.S. coronavirus cases. But some mask manufacturers worry they could be held liable if someone gets sick anyway.

title: Thin Liquidity in Stock Futures Raises Risk of More Wild Market Moves
summary: E-mini liquidity eroded to near record lows during the coronavirus-fueled selloff of late February.

title: Hunger for Safe Assets Pulls Treasury Yields to New Lows
summary: The yield on 10-year Treasurys is on course to close below 1% for a second consecutive day. Treasury yields fell to new lows Thursday, pulled down by investors' appetite for safe assets and wagers that the Federal Reserve will take further action to counter the economic impact of the novel coronavirus.

title: Bank of Canada Mulled Rate Cut Before Virus Risk Escalated
summary: Central bank officials agreed danger of prolonged slowdown outweighed housing, consumer debt risks. TORONTO-A slowing domestic economy meant the Bank of Canada already had a bias toward easing interest rates before considering the impact of the coronavirus epidemic, Gov. Stephen Poloz said Thursday.

title: Schumer Says He Regrets Supreme Court Comments
summary: Senate minority leader says 'I shouldn't have used the words I did, but in no way was I making a threat'. WASHINGTON-Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said he regretted his remarks about two Trump-appointed Supreme Court justices "paying the price" for their potential rulings on abortion, adding they weren't intended as a physical threat.

title: Kroger, Other Retailers See Higher Sales of Staple Goods
summary: Coronavirus epidemic is driving up orders of sanitizers, canned food and nuts. Kroger Co. said it is selling more staple goods as consumers stockpile in preparation for a wider coronavirus outbreak in the U.S.

title: Contributors to the March Men's 2020 Issue
summary: Photographer Juergen Teller, writer Jonah Weiner and others who contributed to the men's spring style issue. For this issue's cover story, A$AP Rocky encountered a few familiar faces. Writer Jonah Weiner interviewed the rapper almost 10 years ago at the start of Rocky's career. "The first time I met him, he was every bit the bright-eyed kid who had just landed himself a $3 million record deal-cocky, for sure, but also kind of pinching himself to make sure he wasn't dreaming," Weiner remembers. "He's nearly a decade older now and unsurprisingly a lot mellower." Stylist Matthew Henson has worked with Rocky for several years. "Each and every time we do a shoot, I leave more and more impressed with him and the work we put in," he says. Collaborating with photographer Juergen Teller, however, was new and momentous for Henson. "The way that Juergen shoots, he's just so sure," Henson says, "and that confidence is infectious."

title: Editor Kristina O'Neill on the Men's Spring Style Issue
summary: Our editor in chief on the men's spring style issue of 'WSJ. Magazine,' featuring cover star A$AP Rocky. This month's cover star, A$AP Rocky, is one of the most restlessly inventive musicians of the day, recording chart-topping albums that meld genres while cultivating a fashion sensibility that blends street style with the European avant-garde. Now, as he prepares to release his fourth studio album, he's found a new measure of international renown: While Rocky was temporarily jailed in Sweden last summer following a street brawl, President Trump lobbied for his release, a fact that came up during the House's impeachment inquiry. "All these old folks know who A$AP Rocky is now," Rocky says with a laugh. "It's hilarious. Old folks be like, 'That A$AP Rocky kid ain't too bad, huh?' "

title: Iran's Coronavirus Crisis Complicated by Lack of Public Confidence in Leaders
summary: The government, already under pressure by U.S. sanctions, is struggling to contain an illness that has sickened dozens of officials. Iran is struggling to contain a virus that has infected scores of officials, shaking the confidence of ordinary Iranians who have been reluctant to follow guidance that could help stem the epidemic.

title: 'Hillary' Review: Inside the Campaign
summary: Hulu's four-part look at Hillary Clinton is a chronicle of her life and career.. If it offered nothing else, "Hillary" (Friday, Hulu) would merit honors for the remarkable frankness of this four-part chronicle of Hillary Clinton's life, career and marriage-a buoyant history, its gut-wrenching aspects notwithstanding. It's difficult to think of any film that speaks to our moment as strikingly as this documentary does, a quality evident early on.

title: 'Amazing Stories: The Cellar' Review: Mystery Awaits
summary: The first installment of this reboot of a 1980s Steven Spielberg series promises adventure.. 'The Cellar" (begins Friday, Apple TV+), executive produced by Steven Spielberg, arrives as the first episode of "Amazing Stories," a reboot of Mr. Spielberg's original fantasy series that aired on NBC from 1985 to 1987. In this hourlong tale-most of whose fascinations worth mentioning can't, in fact, be divulged here-we meet two genial brothers making their way in the world by restructuring and finishing old country houses. The older brother is a family man-he's gay, and he and his partner have a child, all of which testifies to the fact that this series is, indeed, a reboot.

title: In Patagonia, a Master Class in Fly-Fishing (Beginners Welcome)
summary: Argentina's Patagonia is a bucket-list destination for fly-fishing pros. After a week spent on the remote rivers in this natural Eden, two neophytes are ready to join the cult. A WEEK UNLIKE any of the other 3,000 or so I have spent on Earth began as a birthday surprise from my wife. Seven days at a remote fly-fishing lodge in Argentina, in the far south of Patagonia. Here we were, the fly-fishing equivalent of duffers, booked to fish some of the most challenging bucket-list waters in the world. Patagonia is the land of lunkers-huge seagoing brown trout, steelhead, Pacific salmon-in big rivers that demand finesse and serious casting chops. The lodge's list of recommended gear went on for a page: two-handed Spey rods, this and that fly line, flies with names like Woolly Buggers and Chernobyl Ants. "This is some pretty intense stuff, Shailagh," I said to my wife, marveling at the materials. "We'll figure it out," she replied.

title: Oil Prices Fall After OPEC Reaches Deal to Cut Output
summary: The cartel opted to curb production among member nations by 1 million barrels a day in response to reduced demand owing to the coronavirus epidemic. Crude prices fell Thursday as investors waited for the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies to agree on the extent of their response to the coronavirus epidemic's hit on oil demand.

title: 'First Cow': Making Magic From Milk
summary: Kelly Reichardt's latest feature finds friendship and entrepreneurship on the frontier.. Some movies feel dead from the first shot, with or without star power, spectacular vistas or the false energy of hurtling pace. "First Cow" is vividly alive on arrival and grows into pure enchantment, although it starts at a saunter and its physical scale is small. (Even before the lights go down the old-fashioned shape of the nearly square screen announces that visual grandeur won't be on the agenda.)

title: 'The Way Back': On the Rebound
summary: Ben Affleck stars as an alcoholic brought in to coach his alma mater's failing basketball team.. There's plenty of action in "The Way Back," and seething hostility that explodes into rage. Still, the soul of this small, surprising drama lies in other things. The bleak face and gimlet eyes in the mirror after Ben Affleck's alcoholic hero, Jack Cunningham, takes a shower that includes slugging down the can of beer he propped in the soap dish. Jack's forthright, even-toned response when the wife who has left him says he's angry: "I never stop being angry." Like his character, Mr. Affleck has gone through bad times in recent years, both personally and professionally, so the story has extra layers of meaning for him. Taken on its own terms, the film is beautifully crafted, a sequence of events, many of them stirring, along a road to redemption that intersects with a winning group of high-school kids on a losing basketball team.

title: 'Onward': Where Did the Magic Go?
summary: Pixar's latest-about elfin brothers on a quest to reconnect with their dead father-lacks the studio's usual wizardry. With few exceptions, the Pixar logo with the little Luxo lamp has signified something special-not a guarantee of a masterpiece, although we've had plenty of those, but an assurance of humanity, distinctive wit, joyous audacity, startling originality. "Onward," the latest feature from Pixar Animation Studios via Disney, is insistently unspecial. It's enjoyable enough if you don't mind machine-made entertainment, but so desperate to please that it wears out its welcome long before the closing credits.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended February 29
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: U.S. Rebukes International Court Over Afghanistan War Crimes Probe
summary: Washington, which doesn't recognize the court's jurisdiction, has long censured the prosecutor's pursuit of an investigation. The International Criminal Court ruled that its chief prosecutor could investigate alleged war crimes in Afghanistan that may have been committed by U.S. and other forces, deepening a confrontation with the Trump administration.

title: Wearable Devices Take Ergonomics to a New High-Tech Place
summary: The technology-which uses sensors to let warehouse workers know when their posture is off-could reduce injuries from repetitive tasks. The future of industrial ergonomics isn't a person with a clipboard checking workers' posture.

title: Court That Blocked 'Remain in Mexico' Policy Allows Trump Plan to Continue for Now
summary: Appeals court to narrow its ruling, blocking policy of returning immigrants at the border in Arizona and California. A federal appeals court for now agreed to narrow the effect of its recent ruling that blocked a Trump administration policy of returning immigrants at the southern U.S. border to Mexico while their requests for asylum are considered.

title: Senate Passes Coronavirus Spending Bill, Sending Package to Trump
summary: House approved $8.3 billion package a day earlier to address outbreak. WASHINGTON-The Senate passed a roughly $8.3 billion emergency spending bill to combat the coronavirus, sending the legislation to President Trump as lawmakers respond to the outbreak spreading across the country.

title: 'The Hot Wing King' Review: Spicy Family Drama
summary: Katori Hall's latest is the best example yet of her down-to-earth stories bursting with truth. New York

title: Biden Tax Plan Targeting Top Earners Would Raise $4 Trillion in 10 Years, Study Says
summary: Top 1% of households would pay 74% of increased taxes in Biden proposals. WASHINGTON-Former Vice President Joe Biden would raise taxes by $4 trillion over a decade, concentrating those higher levies on top earners, according to a study of his tax proposals.

title: KKR's BlueSprig Buys Florida Autism Center
summary: The deal will expand BlueSprig's ability to provide applied behavior analysis therapy to 1,800 families across 13 states. KKR & Co.'s Blue Sprig Pediatrics Inc. has acquired Florida Autism Center, which also operates in Georgia as Fusion Autism Center.

title: Mortgage Rates Hit Record Low, but Coronavirus May Deter Buyers
summary: The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 3.29%. Mortgage rates fell to their lowest level on record Thursday, pulled down by fears that the spread of coronavirus could weigh on the U.S. economy.

title: Census Bureau Falls Just Short of Applicant Goal for 2020 Count
summary: Government seeks to fill 500,000 temporary positions. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Census Bureau drew fewer applicants than it sought for jobs conducting the 2020 count amid a tight labor market, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said.

title: The Best Ways to Introduce New Technology in the Workplace
summary: Doing it wrong can leave employees angry and alienated. Here's what companies need to keep in mind. When it comes to putting new technology in the workplace, the easiest part is often picking the technology. The trickier part is introducing it to employees.

title: From the Cradle of Civilization
summary: A new exhibition of Mesopotamian treasures and artifacts sheds light on royal power and everyday life.. Asked what he wanted for his 11th birthday, Timothy Potts begged for books about ancient Mesopotamia-an early sign of the passion that would lead him to a distinguished career as a Near Eastern archaeologist and historian. Now director of the J. Paul Getty Museum, Dr. Potts returns to that first love as co-curator of a new exhibition, "Mesopotamia: Civilization Begins," opening at the Getty Villa in Los Angeles on March 18. The show includes more than 200 objects that conjure the texture of life in the ancient region, from sculptures of kings, demons and dogs to brilliant ceramics and cuneiform inscriptions.

title: Ex-Google Self-Driving Engineer Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Anthony Levandowski cites a $179 million legal judgment in dispute that involved Uber. Anthony Levandowski, the self-driving engineer accused by Google of breaching his employment contract and misusing confidential information, filed for bankruptcy, citing a $179 million legal judgment.

title: Coronavirus Fallout Puts Italy at Risk of Recession
summary: Drop in foreign tourists and spending by Italian households threatens to have knock-on effects for the rest of the economy-and Europe. In Milan's historic Savini restaurant, between the city's Duomo cathedral and La Scala opera house, just three of 20 tables had customers on a recent evening, and the normally bustling pedestrian streets nearby were sparsely trod.

title: Goldman Unit in Talks to Buy a Stake in Permira
summary: Private-equity firm is known for backing companies like fashion house Hugo Boss and valuation-advisory company Duff & Phelps. A unit of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is in talks to buy a stake in Permira, a large international private-equity firm, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Everyone Wanted to Touch the Orb. Then It Was Gone.
summary: Glowing globe displayed during a presidential visit to Saudi Arabia captured imaginations, then disappeared. RIYADH-President Trump produced one of the most memorable photos of his presidency when he placed his hands on a glowing Orb at the opening of a new center to combat Islamic extremism during a visit to Saudi Arabia nearly three years ago.

title: Europe Is Long on Worry but Short of the Safest Type of Bonds
summary: Germany's government-bond yields fell the most in Europe during the recent coronavirus market slide. As the economic fallout from the coronavirus spreads across Europe, the safest haven available to investors is in chronically short supply.

title: Elizabeth Warren Drops Out of Presidential Race
summary: Liberal Massachusetts senator ends her run for Democratic nomination after a weak showing on Super Tuesday. Elizabeth Warren, the liberal Massachusetts senator whose policy-oriented pitch to remake Washington and boost the middle class seemed to catch fire in the fall of 2019, ended her bid for the Democratic presidential nomination after a weak showing across a series of states over the past month.

title: Coronavirus Snarls Trans-Pacific Shipping and Ripples Through U.S. Business
summary: There are few China-bound vessels and an imbalance in shipping containers, especially the refrigerated ones used for farm products; 'It's cutthroat'. The coronavirus epidemic is upending the carefully calibrated logistics of global shipping, as plunging exports from China disrupt the trade of American goods, especially farm products such as fruit and meat destined for Asia.

title: The Email Is the Message for Wall Street
summary: Banks' outbound emails to clients jumped 25% on Monday. Markets move. Bankers email.

title: 'Infodemic': When Unreliable Information Spreads Far and Wide
summary: The shorthand term was coined during the SARS outbreak and is back for the new coronavirus.

title: Small Businesses Vote for More Employees
summary: February hiring remained robust according to the NFIB employment report.. Coronavirus concerns didn't stop U.S. small businesses from adding workers last month, and historically tight labor markets continue to drive wages higher. That's according to the February employment report from the National Federation of Independent Business, due out later today. "Strong job creation continued in February, with an average addition of 0.43 workers per firm, adding to a robust 1st quarter of 2020," writes NFIB Chief Economist William Dunkelberg.

title: The Justices Punt on Religious Liberty
summary: They should overturn a 1977 ruling against private employees who need accommodation.. The Supreme Court has passed up an opportunity to strike an overdue blow for religious liberty. On Feb. 24 it rejected the Justice Department's recommendation to hear a dispute between Walgreens and Darrell Patterson, a Seventh-day Adventist who was fired because he missed work on Saturdays.

title: With Cheese, What's Right: Red or White?
summary: A panel of opinionated tasters weighed in on the qualities that make a wine cheese-friendly. These bottles-red, white and sparkling-are the pairings they ranked most pleasing. WINE AND CHEESE are paired together so often that they practically form a single word: wineandcheese. But how often are the two truly a dynamic duo? I find it's often a hit-or-miss match, perhaps because I eat whatever cheese I have on hand with whatever wine I happen to be drinking.

title: Some of Boston's Priciest Real Estate Is Sinking Into the Earth
summary: Resume Subscription. In 2011, developer Koby Kempel paid $2.5 million for a red brick, former carriage house in Boston's coveted Beacon Hill, one of the priciest neighborhoods in the country. Famed for its cobblestone streets and historic row houses, Beacon Hill has been home to former Secretary of State John Kerry and many other notable Bostonians over the years.

title: Coronavirus Exposes How Much Global Steelmakers Rely on China
summary: Even with tariffs blocking China's steel from the U.S. and Europe, the country remains a main supplier of some raw materials producers need. China has long been the world's dominant steelmaker, but the spread of coronavirus has exposed how dependent some global producers are on specialized Chinese raw materials to make the metal.

title: The Mirror That Shakespeare Holds Up to America
summary: John Quincy Adams was a famed abolitionist, but his strong aversion to racial mixing came out in his reaction to 'Othello'. Many Americans hold deep-seated convictions that they are uncomfortable sharing, especially when the subject is divisive. Yet occasionally, the truth will out: While writing a book about the history of Shakespeare in America, I learned that such views often reveal themselves indirectly and unexpectedly, in honest and unguarded responses to Shakespeare's plays.

title: OPEC: From Russia Without Love
summary: A cut from cartel may be too little to stave off further oil-price collapse, and Saudi Arabia will suffer more than most. Russia is playing its cards close to its vest as oil exporters meet in Vienna to deal with the fallout from the spreading coronavirus epidemic. Its decision may not matter much anyway.

title: HP Rejects Xerox's Raised Takeover Offer
summary: Company says a combination would disproportionately benefit Xerox shareholders. HP Inc. rejected Xerox Holdings Corp.'s $35 billion bid to take over the maker of printers, printer supplies and personal computers, again deeming the offer as too low.

title: Coronavirus Fallout Poses Challenges for Most Vulnerable U.S. Retailers
summary: Neiman Marcus, Jo-Ann Stores and other retailers depend on Chinese manufacturers for inventory. The weakest U.S. retailers face the biggest risks from the coronavirus epidemic if Chinese factories overseas remain understaffed and customers at home stay away from bricks-and-mortar stores, according to lenders and analysts.

title: 'Sometimes They're Angry With Us and That's OK': Boeing and 737 MAX Families Form Painful Partnership
summary: Grieving survivors of the 157 dead in Ethiopia crash want to commemorate the site, putting them in a difficult partnership with airline and plane maker. GARA BUKAN, Ethiopia-In the remote fields where an Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 MAX crashed a year ago, the ground is still littered with shards of metal, bolts and colorful bunches of wires that once kept Flight 302 aloft. A solitary hiking boot protrudes from the ground.

title: British Carrier Enters Bankruptcy as Virus Puts Pressure on Airlines
summary: A recent virus-related plunge in bookings forced Flybe's owners to balk at putting any more money into the struggling carrier. The coronavirus outbreak claimed U.K. regional airline carrier Flybe, which entered bankruptcy administration and forced the cancellation of dozens of flights across the country.

title: How to Manage Your Coronavirus Anxiety
summary: The novel coronavirus is making everyone anxious. But there are ways to cope. Here's how.. The novel coronavirus is never far from Mary Yakush's mind. Three or four times a day she visits an online map from Johns Hopkins that tracks the number of cases around the world. She periodically checks news websites for updates on where the virus has spread. And she worries.

title: Media Companies Face New Hurdle as Coronavirus Weighs on Ad Spending
summary: Discretionary spending on ads, a closely watched metric of companies' confidence levels, is slipping. The fallout from the coronavirus epidemic is threatening to weigh on advertising agencies and media companies' operations as the disruption to the global economy from travel bans and quarantines spreads further afield.

title: Cities Built by Royal Command
summary: From ancient Egypt to modern Russia, rulers have tried to build new capitals from the ground up.. In 1420, the Yongle Emperor moved China's capital from Nanjing to the city then known as Beiping. To house his government he built the Forbidden City, the largest wooden complex in the world, with more than 70 palace compounds spread across 178 acres. Incredibly, an army of 100,000 artisans and one million laborers finished the project in only three years. Shortly after moving in, the emperor renamed the city Beijing, "northern capital."

title: Coronavirus Fears Put the Brakes on Pro Cycling
summary: As organizers cancel a major Italian race, five teams suspend part of their season. PARIS-The European cycling season began to buckle under the weight of coronavirus concerns this week as the first major race cancelation hit and several elite teams temporarily withdrew from racing.

title: The Power of Personal Metrics at Work
summary: What can you do to make yourself more productive at your job? What things hold you back? It is time to start measuring yourself. Is it worth taking the time to walk to work, or am I better off spending that half-hour at my desk? Does social media distract me from my work, or is it a useful way to take a break and regain my focus? Are my most profitable projects mostly short-term client engagements, or do I make more money on big, long-term gigs?

title: India Allows Kashmiris on Social Media for First Time in Months
summary: Government temporarily lifts restrictions imposed to mute potential tumult in disputed region. NEW DELHI-India has loosened some restrictions on internet access for the Muslim-majority region of Kashmir, allowing residents direct access to social media for the first time in months, though the easing is temporary and for slow-speed connections.

title: Attendance at Women's College Basketball Games Is Surging
summary: Sabrina Ionescu has turned Oregon women's games into a hot ticket, but the Ducks aren't the only team seeing a boost in popularity. The hottest tickets in college basketball have historically been for games in which the athletes were men. Thanks to a transcendent star and a hotly competitive 2020 season in the women's game, that's starting to change.

title: Demand at Fed's Repo Operations Still Strong, Especially for Longer Loans
summary: Major banks' demand for two-week repos exceeds Fed limit. Major banks' demand for short-term cash from the Federal Reserve remained strong on Thursday, although there was some softening in the appetite for overnight loans.

title: The New Way Online Daters Can Weed Out the Duds
summary: Dating apps are adding video chat to let you screen potential suitors-but is this new layer saving you time and effort or just killing the chemistry?. ANYONE WHO'S tried online dating has experienced it: the bubbly anticipation that arises from those first flirtatious messages-followed by the quick deflation of meeting your match in person. It's tough to set realistic expectations when we create elaborate fantasies around total strangers' dating profiles and their best possible photos (circa 2009).

title: Online Map Tracks Coronavirus Outbreak in Real Time
summary: Website from disease-tracking program HealthMap continuously updates with cases of Covid-19. HealthMap, a program affiliated with the nonprofit Boston Children's Hospital that monitors infectious diseases, has created a digital map using artificial intelligence and other technologies to constantly track the spread of the novel coronavirus.

title: Babies Can Be More Altruistic Than Adults
summary: A new study shows that most toddlers will help a stranger, even if it means giving up a delicious treat.. Toddlers are innocent and sweet, but are they good? Pint-sized autocrats who wake up at dawn, expect food and drink on demand, say no to everything, and who can kick, scream and bite if they don't get their way are called Terrible Twos for a reason.

title: A Manhattan Living Room That's Twice as Nice
summary: A designer helped convince his client to trade up for a "better" apartment across the street. Fortunately, his plan for a $318,000 living/dining area worked out for both spaces. Designer Alexander Doherty had just completed a living room for a client's new pied-à-terre in Manhattan when he came across a nearby industrial building being converted into apartments. He was particularly taken by the 15-foot ceilings. "I thought, 'this could be so much better than what she's about to move into,'" says Mr. Doherty, who runs Alexander Doherty Design. He shared his thoughts with the owner, who works in investments, is in her late 40s and also spends time in Paris and Mexico. She agreed and bought a two-bedroom apartment in the Madison Square park area building. (Her initial apartment is currently being rented.)

title: Focus May Shift to Government Spending to Blunt Coronavirus Impact
summary: If Fed has less scope for action after half-point rate cut, economists suggest fiscal moves will be needed for support. The Federal Reserve's half-point rate cut and market jitters are focusing attention on potential government measures to soften the economic impact of the coronavirus.

title: Coronavirus Piles More Pressure on the Struggling Car Industry
summary: This year is shaping up to be the toughest for manufacturers since 2009 as the epidemic hits auto sales while they're down. Car sales are showing early symptoms of the coronavirus. They could get a whole lot worse if-as seems increasingly likely-more big economies go the way of China, Japan and Italy.

title: Lessons From the Airline Industry's First Coronavirus Bankruptcy
summary: Even a short-term disruption can tip companies with big debts and unproven business models over the edge. Regardless of how long the economic disruption caused by the Covid-19 outbreak turns out to last, it has already tipped at least one troubled company over the edge.

title: 10 Ways to Try Riskier Sneakers
summary: With a suit, denim or off-duty sweats, one of these eccentric pairs of shoes will give your wardrobe the extra bit of style you know it needs. Givenchy earrings, Air Jordan 1 x Union LA sneakers. Stylist's own vintage Levi 501 jeans.

title: Stocks to Watch: Guidewire Software, Zoom Video, United Airlines
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Thursday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: The Knicks Let Spike Lee Walk Out the Door
summary: A standoff with a loyal customer is the latest signal of a tormented franchise that can't seem to get it right. Sometimes I wonder what I would do if the Knicks finally figure it out. On one hand, it would be wonderful. I am old enough to know that, no matter what the Yankees, Rangers, Giants, Jets, Nets, or Mets accomplish, there is nothing quite like New York City when the Knicks are rolling. This noisy town lifts into a whole extra gear. The Knicks don't even have to win championships. They'd just need to be halfway competitive for this melancholy hoops mecca to spring to life again.

title: Stockpilers Buy Up Outdoor Provisions Amid Coronavirus Fears
summary: Makers of snack bars and freeze-dried meals say demand is at record levels.

title: Spending Is Just a Symptom of This Illness
summary: Payments companies say the new coronavirus is hitting some spending, but that isn't the real risk. Global payments companies are seeing a pattern: People are mostly still buying things from other places-they just aren't traveling there.

title: Japan to Quarantine Visitors From China, South Korea
summary: Will also stop issuing visas at its embassies in China and South Korea in attempt to stop spread of coronavirus. TOKYO-Japan introduced some of the strictest border controls aimed at preventing the spread of the new coronavirus, imposing a two-week quarantine on visitors from China or South Korea.

title: Fragile Retirement Funds Tested by Market Volatility, Bond Yields
summary: Pension funds likely shrank about 3% to 5% over the past few weeks, by one estimate. The list of institutions challenged by the impact of the coronavirus now includes America's pension funds.

title: If China Can't Export Medicine, the World Is in Trouble
summary: China is the source of a large percentage of basic drug ingredients. Much of the contents of your medicine cabinet can be traced back to Chinese ingredients processed into pills in India. Thanks to the coronavirus, much of Chinese industry remains shut down. The potential ramifications of that for pharmaceuticals are now becoming clear.

title: Bloomberg's Campaign Was Like No Other
summary: Billionaire candidate built a huge operation in which money was never a worry. About a week before Super Tuesday, Michael Bloomberg's campaign staffers gathered at the Hard Rock Cafe at Times Square-around the corner from their Manhattan headquarters-to celebrate.

title: No Crowds at the Mona Lisa: Coronavirus Fears Hammer European Tourism
summary: Outbreak comes at the start of the period when people book their spring and summer travel plans. PARIS-The Mona Lisa's daily crowd of admirers has thinned.

title: Coronavirus Epidemic Draws Scrutiny to Labs Handling Deadly Pathogens
summary: Risk of accidents or terrorism grows as more countries handle exotic microbes, say biosafety experts. SHANGHAI-Scientists at a specialized Wuhan laboratory have been at the forefront of China's response to its continuing coronavirus epidemic but are drawing attention to risks associated with the expanding global study of deadly pathogens.

title: Music Labels Need to Get Their IPO Timing Right
summary: Warner Music is pressing pause on its listing plans as markets turn volatile, but should keep the delay short. The coronavirus has claimed at least one victim in the world of initial public offerings: Warner Music Group has paused plans to return to Wall Street. It would be wise to press ahead as soon as the stock market finds a surer footing.

title: Justices Voice Clashing Views Over Louisiana Abortion Law
summary: Statute requires doctors performing procedure to hold admitting privileges at a hospital no more than 30 miles away. WASHINGTON-Supreme Court justices voiced clashing views in a case that will test whether a more conservative high court will move to narrow access to abortions.

title: Working From Home Because of Coronavirus? These Are Your Tech Fixes
summary: A look at the biggest work-from-home tech annoyances and solutions. And on the umpteenth day of the coronavirus panic, the overlords commanded: Thou shalt work from home.

title: Another Princess Cruise Ship Is Caught Up in Coronavirus Outbreak
summary: California health officials say other former passengers may have been infected; 'You may order room service'. SAN FRANCISCO-Another Carnival Corp. cruise ship has become embroiled in an outbreak of Covid-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus-this time in a West Coast-based liner called the Grand Princess where health officials say at least one former passenger has died after a recent cruise.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Yeshiva University Basketball Team Racks Up Faithful Fans With Win Streak
summary: Maccabees have a record winning streak of 27 games this season, and are now headed for the NCAA Division III tournament. A few years ago, when Yeshiva University's Maccabees basketball team played a game, it barely drew 30 spectators.

title: After Losing Cargo Ship to U.S., North Korea Found Another in Vietnam
summary: Pyongyang replaced ship seized by U.S., in sign the country keeps finding ways to evade export sanctions. When the U.S. seized control of one of North Korea's largest cargo ships last year, American authorities said the loss would significantly disrupt Pyongyang's ability to flout sanctions and keep exporting commodities such as coal.

title: Javier Perez de Cuellar, Peruvian Diplomat and U.N. Chief, Dies
summary: When he left office as secretary-general, he had attained a peace pact between the Salvadoran government and leftist rebels. LIMA, Peru-Javier Perez de Cuellar, the two-term United Nations secretary-general who brokered a historic cease-fire between Iran and Iraq in 1988 and later came out of retirement to help re-establish democracy in his Peruvian homeland, died Wednesday, Peru's foreign ministry said. He was 100.

title: Chief Justice John Roberts Rebukes Chuck Schumer Over 'Pay the Price' Comments
summary: Senate minority leader warned Trump-appointed Justices Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh on vote against abortion rights. WASHINGTON-Chief Justice John Roberts on Wednesday criticized the Senate's top Democrat for saying the Supreme Court's two Trump appointees will "pay the price" should they vote against abortion rights.

title: United Airlines Cuts U.S., International Flights in Response to Coronavirus
summary: Air carrier slicing domestic flying by 10%, international by 20% in April. United Airlines Holdings Inc. said it would cut domestic flights, as the spreading coronavirus depresses bookings.

title: SEC Plan Would Allow Startups to Raise More Money Under Light-Touch Rules
summary: Under the plan, crowdfunding limit would be raised to $5 million from $1 million. WASHINGTON-Startups and small companies would be allowed to raise more money from investors when they opt for light-touch fundraising methods under a plan made public Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Stocks Rally as Super Tuesday Results Buoy Health Insurers
summary: DJIA rose nearly 1,200 points; bond yields hover near record lows. U.S. stocks surged Wednesday as a strong Super Tuesday performance by former Vice President Joe Biden and growing signs of a coordinated response to the coronavirus reassured jittery investors.

title: U.S. Death Toll From Coronavirus Rises to 11
summary: Fatalities grew with California announcing its first death, which it linked to a cruise ship that sailed to Mexico. The U.S. death toll from the new coronavirus grew to 11 Wednesday, with California announcing its first fatality linked to the viral infection and Washington state reporting its 10th death.

title: House Passes $8.3 Billion Bill to Battle Coronavirus
summary: Lawmakers agree on funding for response to outbreak spreading across the country. WASHINGTON-The House passed a roughly $8.3 billion emergency spending package for combating the coronavirus outbreak, sending the legislation to the Senate as lawmakers raced to respond to the quickly spreading outbreak.

title: U.S. Delays New Data-Release Policy, in Win for Media Firms
summary: Government says plan to post economic data on website is fairer to investors. The Labor Department is suspending a plan to change how it releases economic data, in a win for financial-media firms that had lobbied against the changes.

title: New York City Teacher Shows Coronavirus Symptoms
summary: Patient recently returned from Italy, and illness appeared after several days in classroom. A New York City public-school teacher who recently traveled to Italy is under self-quarantine after showing symptoms of the new coronavirus, prompting city officials to give her school a deep clean and to have disease specialists retrace her steps, officials said Wednesday.

title: Eleven New Yorkers Have Coronavirus
summary: Number of virus cases is expected to grow, state officials say. Eleven New Yorkers, including nine members of two Westchester County families, have tested positive for the new coronavirus, and the number of cases is expected to grow, state officials said Wednesday.

title: Joe Biden's Stock-Market Tonic
summary: Health shares soar as the threat of Medicare for All recedes.. Divining the logic of stock-market moves is tricky business, but that sure was some rally on Wednesday. While coronavirus cases continued to spread, investors seemed pleased that the political threat of a Bernie Sanders Presidency has receded.

title: The Sanders vs. Biden Stakes
summary: Joe has the broader coalition but Bernie will fight to the end.. Hold the revolution. The Bernie Sanders takeover of the Democratic Party took a detour on Super Tuesday with Joe Biden's stunning victories that have now made this a two-man race for the nomination. Maybe President Trump wished too soon, and too noticeably, for Mr. Sanders as his opponent.

title: Schumer Threatens the Court
summary: The leading Senate Democrat draws a rebuke from Roberts.. Democrats like to accuse President Trump of violating institutional democratic norms, and often he does with his rhetorical broadsides. But at least he's never directly threatened the U.S. Supreme Court the way Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer did on Wednesday.

title: Bloomberg's Contribution
summary: His candidacy offers some valuable lessons in presidential politics.. Michael Bloomberg is being widely mocked for spending more than $500 million to run for President and winning . . . American Samoa. We think he deserves credit for trying when he could have sat on the sidelines and carped about how the Democrats were blowing their chance to defeat Donald Trump with a socialist nominee.

title: Senate Passes Bill Requiring 5G Security Review
summary: Bill reflects concerns that foreign countries could spy on data flowing through U.S. telecom networks. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Senate passed legislation that would require the Trump administration to identify security threats and possible fixes within the equipment and software that support 5G wireless networks.

title: California Teachers' Pension Takes Stock of Coronavirus Impact
summary: The effects of the coronavirus on one of the largest U.S. public pension systems has been limited by the structure of its private-equity investments. One of the biggest public pension funds in the U.S. has begun tallying the costs-and in some cases, gains-from the coronavirus outbreak sweeping the world.

title: The Misguided Progressive Attack on Charters
summary: Traditional districts are often much worse when it comes to unaccountability and 'creaming' of students.. Charter schools used to be a bipartisan education reform, but Democrats have turned against it of late. Many of their complaints are bad-faith projections-criticism for problems that aren't unique to charters but endemic throughout the public education system.

title: Bonds Aren't as Safe as You Think
summary: If interest rates rise, they'll plummet in value, forcing investors to sell at a loss or stay trapped for years.. Investment risk has never been more challenging to gauge. Before last week's market decline, it would have been almost laughable to suggest that investors should stay on the sidelines. After all, the S&P 500 gained 30% in 2019-despite trade tensions and slow growth overseas. And then the floor dropped out from under the stock market.

title: The Case for Ginsburg to Recuse Herself
summary: Unlike Sotomayor, she has shown bias against Trump by publicly characterizing him as unfit for office.. President Trump recently lashed out at Justices Sonia Sotomayor and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. "Both should recuse themselves on all Trump, or Trump related, matters!" he tweeted. He's wrong about Justice Sotomayor but has a point about Justice Ginsburg.

title: Zoom Video Posts Fourth-Quarter Net Profit on 78% Revenue Growth
summary: Its shares have risen as several companies have replaced planned gatherings with online events. Zoom Video Communications Inc. posted 78% quarterly sales growth, which disappointed some investors who had been betting the videoconferencing company would post stronger numbers as the spread of the coronavirus drives businesses to replace some in-person gatherings with online meetings.

title: China Imprisons a Swedish Bookseller
summary: The treatment of Gui Minhai is a threat to international order.. The sentencing of bookseller Gui Minhai to 10 years in Chinese prison is another example of the Chinese Communist Party's willingness to trample on the rule of law and thumb its nose at the world. The Chinese-born Mr. Gui is a Swedish citizen, yet China has forced him to renounce his rights as a foreigner. Sweden's diplomats were barred from observing his trial and have been denied consular access.

title: 'The Bilingual Brain' Review: Two Souls in One Body
summary: Researchers still struggle to understand how our minds access two languages. A Spanish race-car driver suffered a concussive accident and reportedly woke up speaking just his second language, Italian.. In his dystopian novel "Nineteen Eighty-Four," George Orwell imagined an artificial language, Newspeak, whose restricted grammar and vocabulary were designed to limit the freedom of thought. Although that was clearly an extreme scenario, might those who speak a second language find their thoughts and behavior shaped in some lesser and more benign manner by the words they choose? In his lucid and fascinating book "The Bilingual Brain," Albert Costa forensically explores how different languages coexist within a single human brain, locked into a functional and perpetual-although sometimes awkward and uncomfortable-embrace.

title: A Successful Mideast Nuclear Deal
summary: The United Arab Emirates finishes loading fuel in its new civilian nuclear power plant.. The Middle East nuclear agreement is working well. It contains the strongest commitments ever agreed to for nonproliferation and transparency and no pathway to weaponization. No, not that nuclear deal.

title: Socialism Just Bombed
summary: Hard to believe these days, but voters still get the last word on what they want from our politics.. Joe Biden's back-from-the-dead primary wins this week were remarkable, but they aren't the biggest story. Super Tuesday was a wake-up call for this country's understanding of who we are and what we want from our politics and culture.

title: Our House Is Divided. Whither Cooperation?
summary: In "America's House Divided Cannot Stand" Charles Lipson is equating conservatism with liberalism, as though there is just a civil disagreement over policy.. In "America's House Divided Cannot Stand" (op-ed, Feb. 25), Charles Lipson is equating conservatism with liberalism, as though there is just a civil disagreement over policy. That is not really true. It has been liberalism, and more recently leftism, that wants to "radically transform America" and completely upend the constitutional order. It started in the 1950s with the Warren Court's judicial activism. While the Brown v. Board of Education decision is often used as justification, that decision actually reversed the activism of the 1896 Supreme Court, which created out of whole cloth an unconstitutional concept known as "separate but equal." But other decisions by the court were activist in nature, the best example being its creation of a right to abortion, also out of whole cloth. The court gave itself so much power over our daily lives that court vacancies, at least under Republican presidents, now result in ugly spectacles.

title: Turning Appalachian Trail Into a Green Wall
summary: The idea that the 2,200-mile trail, under which more than 50 pipelines already pass, should become a Berlin Wall separating the Eastern Seaboard from the rest of the U.S. is ridiculous.. Your editorial "The Lorax on the Appalachian Trail" (Feb. 24) shows the legal contortions antienergy groups have carried out to block the Atlantic Coast and Mountain Valley pipelines. The Fourth Circuit ruling giving the National Park Service control of Forest Service land hundreds feet under the trail is as fantastical as the Dr. Seuss character.

title: U.S.-Taliban Deal Comes Under Pressure Amid Military Action
summary: U.S. troops will begin leaving this week, but key parts of the agreement between the Trump administration and Afghan insurgents are in question. BEIRUT-The Trump administration is facing an uphill battle to keep a landmark agreement with the Taliban on track after a resurgence of violence and growing diplomatic strain between Washington and Kabul.

title: Covid-19: Don't Reach Out and Touch That
summary: Smartphone apps could eliminate contagion from all kinds of transactions that involve touching shared, public objects like ATMs, library catalogue screens, point-of-sale devices and immigration terminals.. Regarding Carl Carthy's Feb. 27 letter about unsanitized and unsanitary touch screens, particularly in the age of coronavirus: Although the risk of catching the novel coronavirus from such devices is currently low in the U.S. because the number of coronavirus-infected people is low, there are other viruses (e.g., influenza) that can also cause significant harm to people.

title: Are Democrats Preparing Another Anti-Bernie Fix?
summary: Even if Sen. Sanders enters Milwaukee in July with more than 1,990 "pledged" delegates, I'll bet that somehow, some way, the outcome will be changed to Sen. Sanders's disadvantage.. Reading Karl Rove's "Last Stand Against Bernie Sanders" (op-ed, Feb. 27) reminds me of Groucho Marx's line "Those are my principles, and if you don't like them . . . well I have others." Many Democratic Party poohbahs probably feel the same way about their national convention rules. Rules?

title: Keep Perspective on Natural And Man-Made Disasters
summary: I'm mildly perplexed by Holman Jenkins's suggestion that aerosol manipulation of the earth's atmosphere "to offset the warming seen so far" might not be prohibitively costly. What if it worked?. As an unreserved admirer of Holman Jenkins's skill in keeping his eye on the ball, I'm mildly perplexed by his suggestion that aerosol manipulation of the earth's atmosphere "to offset the warming seen so far" might not be prohibitively costly ("How Bezos Can Influence Climate," Business World, Feb. 26) I can only repeat the question I've asked over and over again in my professional capacity during the past 20 years: What if we tried something like that, and it worked?
